results.title: The Enchanted miller
results.creator_credit: Czechoslovak State Film, Official Films and Josef Vacha
results.brief_description: A cartoon version of a folk tale. A water demon has enchanted a mill and put its workers to flight. He torments them and continually evades their clutches by changing his shape. Finally they catch him and cut off his coat tails, thus depriving him of his magic powers.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Czechoslovak State Film, Official Films and Josef Vacha

results.title: The Emu and the sun
results.brief_description: An animated film based on an Aboriginal legend about how emus became wingless birds and how sunlight came to earth.

results.title: The Empty seas
results.creator_credit: James Carr, World Wide Pictures and Henri Fabiani
results.brief_description: Camaret, on the coast of Brittany, relies on lobster fishing and boat building for its livelihood. However, some areas are being fished out and the industry is dying. Shows the continued, and often unrewarded, toil of the men on one of the lobster boats, whose search extends as far as South America and Mauritania.

results.title: The Empty quarter
results.creator_credit: Mostafa Hammuri, I T T Productions and Richard Taylor
results.brief_description: Traces the expedition of the Englishman, Wilfred Patrick Thesiger, through the desert of South Arabia, the home of the Bedouin. Provides an intimate insight into the life and customs of the inhabitants of the ‘Empty Quarter’ of Arabia

results.title: The Empty pillow = Al-Wisada al-khalia = Illussions d'amour
results.creator_credit: Ramsis Naguib, Le Societe Arabe pour le Cinema, Arabic Cinema and Salah Abou Seif
results.brief_description: Romantic drama starring Abdel Halim Hafez as the young student Salah who falls in love with the innocent Samiha played by Lubna Abdel Aziz. However Samiha’s parents have other ideas - they want Samiha to marry the wealthy Dr Fouad. Desperate, Salah decides to take matters into his own hands with unexpected consequences. Photography by Mahmoud Nasr.
results.title_for_label: The Empty pillow = Al-Wisada al-khalia = Illussions d’amour

results.title: The Empty nest
results.creator_credit: Learning Corporation of America, Jonathan Kress and Judith Kress
results.brief_description: Tells of the threat of extinction to the osprey (fish hawk); since 1950, 90% of these birds have vanished due to the effects of pesticides. Studies the bird’s courtship, rearing of young, flight patterns and habits. Tells of the effects of pesticides in relation to the food chain.

results.title: The Empty hand
results.brief_description: Karate means “empty hand” in Japanese. Filmed at a Karate school in New York, “black belt” experts demonstrate the Japanese art of defending oneself without use of weapons by striking an attacker with the hands, elbows, knees or feet. Winner of a Cine Golden Eagle and nine other international festival awards.

results.title: The Empty frame
results.brief_description: The biography of Robert Goddard and the history of the development of rocketry. Shows how Goddard’s research and developmental work, with respect to rocketry, made possible the great space exploration vehicles of today. Includes archival footage

results.title: The Empire strikes back (Captioned)
results.brief_description: The battle to save the galaxy from the evil Darth Vader rages on in this spellbinding Star Wars sequel. In a spectacular opening battle the Rebels suffer a devastating attack by an Imperial Army using ATAT walkers. Hans Solo, Princess Leia and Chewbacca survive, and fight a running space battle against Imperial ships while Luke Skywalker seeks out Yoda, the ancient Jedi Master, to be trained as a true Jedi Knight. Rated: PG Caption Version only Available.

results.title: The Empire of signs
results.creator_credit: Julia Cave, Time Inc and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “American visions”.
This episode deals with some of the truths and illusions in America’s development as a huge-scale cultural consumer from 1950 through the end of the 1970s. It can be seen, in retrospect, how cultural patterns follow changes of attitude socially and politically. “Having the bomb confirmed the old belief in American exceptionalism,” says Hughes. The last half of the twentieth century was to be “The American Century” and, between 1945 and the late 1960s, New York succeeded Paris as the Western world’s art capital. The American styles that carried its reputation were Abstract Expressionism. The work of Jackson Pollock, Willem de Kooning, Mark Rothko, Robert Motherwell, Barnett Newman and others, and its successor, Pop Art. The Pop Art movement was created by figures such as Robert Rauschenberg, Jasper Johns and Andy Warhol. Hughes considers how Abstract Expressionism and Pop Art fit into a global America of nuclear anxiety and chromium opulence, and what happens to the avant-garde when the pursuit of the new becomes America’s official culture. Written and presented by Robert Hughes.
